kb_snippets.q: What is the accounting equation?
kb_snippets.a: The accounting equation states that Assets = Liabilities + Equity. It must hold after every transaction; it’s the basis of double-entry and the balance sheet.

kb_snippets.q: How do debits and credits relate to the equation?
kb_snippets.a: Debits increase assets and expenses; credits increase equity, income, and liabilities. Every transaction posts equal debits and credits to keep A = L + E.

kb_snippets.q: Why does the equation matter for PoA and heroBooks?
kb_snippets.a: It underpins the balance sheet tested in CXC PoA and ensures your ledger stays in balance in heroBooks after every journal or document you post.

kb_snippets.q: When do I expense vs capitalise a repair?
kb_snippets.a: Expense routine servicing; capitalise replacements or upgrades that increase future benefits or extend useful life—then derecognise the replaced part.

kb_snippets.q: Do I derecognise the old component?
kb_snippets.a: Yes. When a significant part is replaced, remove the carrying amount of the old part from PPE and recognise the new part at cost.

kb_snippets.q: Can I claim VAT on repairs/improvements?
kb_snippets.a: If used to make taxable supplies, input VAT is generally recoverable; follow GRA rules (partial exemption if you have exempt outputs; special rules for zero-rated capital equipment).

kb_snippets.q: What is an appropriation account in a partnership?
kb_snippets.a: It shows how net profit is divided among partners after charging items like partners’ salaries and interest on capital and after crediting interest on drawings.

kb_snippets.q: What’s the difference between capital and current accounts?
kb_snippets.a: Capital accounts record long-term investment; current accounts track routine allocations (salary, interest on capital/drawings, share of profit) and drawings during the year.

kb_snippets.q: How are profits shared?
kb_snippets.a: As per the partnership agreement — common methods are equally, fixed percentage, or capital ratio. If no agreement, assume equal.

kb_snippets.q: What’s the difference between accrual and cash?
kb_snippets.a: Accrual recognises income/expenses when earned/incurred; cash when paid/received. Accrual is used for financial statements under IFRS for SMEs.

kb_snippets.q: How does this affect VAT in Guyana?
kb_snippets.a: VAT follows “time of supply” rules. You must issue Tax Invoices and, if pricing is VAT-inclusive, use the 7/57 fraction to back out VAT.

kb_snippets.q: When is my VAT return due?
kb_snippets.a: On or before the 21st of the following month (or next business day).

kb_snippets.a: No. Section 11 uses an incurred-loss impairment approach for financial assets at cost or amortised cost. Recognise impairment when there is objective evidence a loss event occurred (e.g., default, significant financial difficulty).

kb_snippets.q: What are bank rules?
kb_snippets.a: Bank rules automatically suggest or post categories, tax codes, and payees for repeating or similar bank-feed lines (for example, mobile top-ups or fuel). Used well, they reduce manual data entry while keeping a clear audit trail.

kb_snippets.q: How do I add a bank rule in heroBooks?
kb_snippets.a: Go to **Banking → Imports**, filter a repeating line, then create a rule with conditions (payee text, reference, amount range). Choose the **account**, **VAT code** (14%, zero-rated, exempt), and whether to auto-post or just suggest. Test on recent lines before enabling auto-post.

kb_snippets.q: What are common mistakes with bank rules?
kb_snippets.a: Over-broad text matches, missing VAT codes, ignoring split transactions (fuel + shop), and never reviewing exceptions. Use “suggest only” first; sample-test 10–20 lines monthly.

kb_snippets.q: What’s the quick test for capex vs revenue?
kb_snippets.a: Capex if the spend creates a new asset or enhances/extends the asset’s useful life beyond original; routine repair to maintain condition is revenue.

kb_snippets.q: How do I correct a misclassification?
kb_snippets.a: Reclassify with a journal (e.g., Dr PPE / Cr Repairs), adjust depreciation if necessary, and disclose if material.

kb_snippets.q: What’s a solid day-close routine?
kb_snippets.a: Count each till, reconcile to POS Z-report (sales, refunds, VAT), prepare the bank deposit, and log over/short with a second person observing. Post a single summary journal for the day.

kb_snippets.q: How should VAT be handled for cash sales?
kb_snippets.a: If prices are VAT-inclusive, extract output VAT using the 14/114 fraction (i.e., 7/57 of the gross) before posting revenue. Keep Z-reports and tax-invoice ranges.

kb_snippets.q: What are the classic cash schemes?
kb_snippets.a: **Skimming** (off-book theft before recording) and **larceny** (after recording: false voids/returns, short banking). Watch for unusual refunds, no-sale pops, and delayed deposits.

kb_snippets.q: When do I open a suspense account?

kb_snippets.q: What errors keep the TB balanced?
kb_snippets.a: Errors of omission, commission, principle, original entry, or compensating errors. These won’t create a TB difference, so no suspense is needed—fix with proper journals.

kb_snippets.q: How do I use a suspense account properly?
kb_snippets.a: Only to park the TB difference while you investigate; then fully clear it by posting the identified fixes. Keep a short narrative with each correcting journal.

kb_snippets.q: What are the three trial balances?
kb_snippets.a: Unadjusted (before period-end journals), Adjusted (after accruals, prepayments, depreciation, etc.), and Post-closing (after closing temporary accounts; only balance-sheet accounts remain).

kb_snippets.q: Does a balanced TB prove there are no errors?
kb_snippets.a: No. It catches math/posting errors but not omissions, misclassifications, compensating errors, or equal-and-opposite mistakes.

kb_snippets.q: What’s the audit shortcut?
kb_snippets.a: Pick a sample, confirm **rate** (14%/0%/exempt), test math (e.g., use **7/57** for VAT-inclusive prices), confirm support (Schedule 1/Act) and that summaries post to the right VAT boxes.

kb_snippets.q: How do I absorb overhead to WIP?
kb_snippets.a: Apply a rate (e.g., % of labour or machine hours): Dr WIP — overhead absorbed / Cr Overhead control; true‑up variances at period end.

kb_snippets.q: How do I treat under-absorbed overhead?
kb_snippets.a: Dr COGS (or variance account) / Cr Overhead control; analyze for rate reset.

kb_snippets.q: Where is the variance log CSV?
kb_snippets.a: Download /kb/templates/wip-variance-log.csv and require root-cause and closure owner.

kb_snippets.q: What’s the difference between zero-rated and exempt?
kb_snippets.a: Zero-rated is a taxable supply at 0% (usually allows input VAT recovery); exempt is non-taxable (input VAT not recoverable). See this article for examples and invoicing notes.

kb_snippets.q: What should my invoice say?
kb_snippets.a: Tag each line explicitly as “Zero-rated” or “Exempt” and follow the Tax Invoice fields GRA lists (or Sales Invoice where permitted). See the “Invoice & label rules” section.
